Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I was halfway through trimming Mrs. Lee’s fringe when she smiled at me in the mirror and asked, “Could you just take a little more off the left side?” She’s been coming to me for years, always cheerful, always trusting. I nodded, but my mind was racing. I’d just remembered that my ID was still at home, and today was the only morning I could grab it before work. The polls are open tomorrow, but I won’t have another chance to get my ID before then. I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me—Mrs. Lee expected her hair to be perfect, and I owed her my full attention. But as a voter, I had a responsibility to show up prepared, to make my voice count. My hands hesitated with the scissors, torn between finishing her cut with care and the urgent need to dash home. The clock on the wall ticked louder, and I could feel my heart pounding, caught between being the reliable hairdresser and the responsible citizen.
